destination.label: Cayenne
destination.title: Cayenne: France at the other end of the world

content.intro:
French Amazon is a land of luxurious nature that you can discover onboard a dugout canoe, looking for wild birds and camping along the Approuague River. Cultivate your childhood dreams, be an adventurer, a parrot seeker or an explorer of uncharted territories.

Whether under blazing sun or heavy rain, the extraordinary lushness of the Amazon is astounding for its incredible plant and animal diversity. From the tree canopy to the mangrove, the savannah to the marshes, the rustling landscapes play an invisible melody in which animal, bird, and insect communication are woven together. Symbol of geographical, human, and cultural multiplicity, French Guiana is a favourite destination for contemporary explorers, but it will not leave anyone indifferent. There are countless faces in this unique part of the Amazon, an intricate mosaic of languages and ethnicities carved over the centuries and enriched by wave upon wave of immigration. The Guianese embrace their Native American heritage, yet the country is inhabited by people from five continents, with 45% of the population under the age of 20. While all seek entry into the third millennium, a dream incompatible with the preservation of this exceptional environment, their lifestyles, festivals, traditions, and religions have helped build a model of multiculturalism that will be greatly appreciated for its true value by any traveller who cares for humanity. With so many isolated areas and very few roads, French Guiana remains a land of adventure best travelled by canoe, on capricious rivers bristling with waterfalls and rapids. You will quickly realize that time has a different value here, and life is organized in harmony with nature. It is the jungle itself that imposes this philosophy; we are light years from urban stress. Long before the space centre in Kourou (in the 18th century actually), Cayenne was a centre of astronomical experimentation, but its heyday really began in 1854 with the discovery of gold and a host of mineral resources. The most populous city of the department today is the proud face of this exotic province, which is rehabilitating its rich creole heritage at its own pace, revisiting the past while coming to terms with the present.

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in French Guiana

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Cayenne

content.title: La Petite Maison, Creole-style fine dining

introduction.small: Amid a typical Creole house in Cayenne, La Petite Maison highlights the Guianese culinary heritage, fine-tuned into high gastronomy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Petite Maison, Creole-style fine dining

paragraphs.text:
Before you even stepped inside, La Petite Maison catches the eye as you walk around the streets of Cayenne. Everything about this colourful and typically Creole building oozes authenticity. Entirely renovated while being converted into a bistronomic restaurant, it offers a mesmerizing setting, absolutely charming and worth the detour in itself!

Start off the proceedings with serene pre-dinner drinks on the peaceful terrace, before moving inside the house. For a romantic dinner, ask for one of the more intimate tables on the first floor - the staff is especially attentive and caring with passing patrons. Once settled, a ballet of gastronomic proportions will dazzle you: sea bass steak in smoked fish crust, crispy weakfish in vegetarian hot pepper cream, or a steak of king mackerel served with sweet potato dumplings, topped with hot sauce chien using green condiments… Modernised Creole flavours await aplenty! Most importantly, each dish is neatly displayed in careful servings. The restaurant revisits Guianese cuisine with contemporary overtones that turn it into fine art.

La Petite Maison
23 rue Félix Éboué
97300 Cayenne

+594 (0)594 38 58 39

https://www.restaurantlapetitemaison.com

Carte : environ 37 EUR

content.title: A change of scenery at Hôtel Ker Alberte

introduction.small: Located in the centre of town just a few steps from the Ocean, the Hôtel Ker Alberte is the ideal starting point for your discovery of Cayenne, the capital of French Guiana.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A change of scenery at Hôtel Ker Alberte

paragraphs.text:
In downtown Cayenne, between the market and the Place des Palmistes, discover the charm of a creole house dating to 1912. This is where Hôtel Ker Alberte has been established after a complete and respectful renovation that has preserved its authenticity.

There are 15 guest rooms, as well as apartments for longer stays. The decoration is very contemporary, in shades of white and cream. The linens provide touches of colour that will brighten your room.

Outdoor passageways overlook the pool, surrounded by a tropical garden as tranquil as they come. If you are looking for a change of scenery, this is the place to be. Le K Restaurant serves fresh, entirely homemade market cuisine. The menu brings forth traditional gastronomy with a modern twist. Comfortably set by the pool in the cool shade of the gazebo, take your pick among mussels in vegetarian hot pepper, grilled octopus and sweet potato cream, or duck breasts in orange served with fig and mango cream… Paired with wines from the restaurant's cellar, this sophisticated cuisine blends perfectly with the musical mood of Friday nights: you will be able to dine to the sounds of a jazz concert. Cosy atmosphere is not an option!

Hôtel Ker Alberte
4 rue du Docteur Sainte Rose
97300 Cayenne

+594 (0)5 94 25 75 70

hotelkeralberte.com/hotel_keralberte/index.php/en/

Rooms: from 190 EUR

Restaurant menu: around EUR 36

content.title: Lodges Balourou: a pioneer in eco-tourism

introduction.small: Close to nature with its impeccable bungalows facing the sea and its tropical garden, this small hotel goes all out!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lodges Balourou: a pioneer in eco-tourism

paragraphs.text:
The beautiful village of Remire-Montjoly, in the green suburbs of Cayenne, is bordered by long sandy beaches. Once a Native American agricultural area, many vestiges of its past remain, including petroglyphs at Crique Pavé and on the hillsides of Montravel, and engraved stones from the pre-Columbian era at the much-visited Habitation Pascaud. Fort Diamant, a listed building constructed in 1849, served as a strategic defence against the Portuguese.

A stay at the Lodge is always relaxing: birdsong and the murmur of waves are the dominant sounds; and the owners are ever friendly and always smiling. The air-conditioned lodges have one or two bedrooms, with kitchenettes and Wi-Fi. All terraces and balconies have nice views of the sea or the mouth of the river.

Lodges Balourou
6836 route des plages
97354 Remire-Montjoly

+594 (0)6 94 21 88 72

https://lodgesbalourou.fr/

Rooms: from 80 EUR

content.title: Grand Hôtel Montabo: perfect beach holiday headquarters

introduction.small: Sleep at the Grand Hôtel Montabo, situated close to sea turtles as they lay eggs on their favourite beach.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grand Hôtel Montabo: perfect beach holiday headquarters

paragraphs.text:
Three kilometres from the city centre and very close to Montabo Beach, a nesting ground for sea turtles and an important eco-tourism site, this beautiful hotel has 103 air-conditioned rooms (including two suites) and all the mod cons, including satellite TV and Wi-Fi. Ask for one with a view of the gardens.

The business centre offers a range of services, including secretarial and audio-visual equipment. The spa is well appointed, and the outdoor pool is in a very lush setting. At the end of the day, they provide some well-earned relaxation.

The restaurant's lunch and dinner menus offer European classics mixed with some local specialities.

The stylish lounge bar gets busy in the early evening and deserves a visit if not for its selection of cocktails from around the world, then for its famous and very full-bodied Ti' punch.

Grand Hôtel Montabo
Route de Montabo
Chemin Hilaire
97300 Cayenne

+594 (0)5 94 30 38 88

https://www.grand-hotel-montabo.fr/en/

Rooms: from 125 EUR

content.title: Visiting the indigenous peoples: two days on the Maroni

introduction.small: A highway on water through thick jungle, the Maroni River is the only means of connecting with the Amerindian and Bushinengue villages scattered along its banks.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Visiting the indigenous peoples: two days on the Maroni

paragraphs.text:
Named a 'Ville d'Art et d'Histoire' ('City of Art and History') by the French government in 2007, Saint-Laurent-du-Maroni, a border town next to Surinam in northwest French Guiana, is the second largest city in French Guiana. Its pre-Columbian roots and timeless bond with its river, the Moroni, one of the most extensively studied of all the rivers in the Amazon basin, make it a popular destination among adventure sports enthusiasts looking to make real contact with the natural and cultural wealth of the rainforest and its peoples.

Travelling upriver toward Maripasoula by pirogue is a once-in-a-lifetime experience, a truly unusual sports adventure that also conveys a sensible approach and understanding of the inhabitants of the primal forest. It is an opportunity to see unscathed landscapes, navigate rapids, swim in secret coves, and spend nights in a “Carbet” traditional hut, or in a hammock, lulled by the unusual exhalations of the forest.

Saint-Laurent-du-Maroni
Guyane française
https://www.saintlaurentdumaroni.fr

Takari Amazonie
Zi Terca
CC Family Plaza
97351 Matoury
+594 (0)5 94 28 70 00
www.takari-amazonie.com/sejour/la-descente-ou-la-remontee-du-maroni/

content.title: Museum of French Guianese Culture: a historical witness

introduction.small: A spectacular collection of ethnographic objects from the many peoples who built French Guiana, from the first Native American settlements to the recent immigration of Hmong and Haitians.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museum of French Guianese Culture: a historical witness

paragraphs.text:
Since 2010, the cities of Belém in Brazil and Paramaribo in Surinam joined forces with French Guiana to create a network of Amazon museums. Established in 1995 and housed in a renovated creole house downtown, this museum has been labelled 'Musée de France'. Its rich collections reflect the cultural diversity of French Guiana, with Native American and colonial archaeology departments, iconographic and historical collections, as well as sound and documentary archives.

Because of a lack of space, the rue Madame Payé accommodates the two annexes. The first is at No. 54, a reconstruction of an old creole house that belonged to Herménégilde Tell, Félix Éboué's father-in-law. It reveals past ways of life in urban milieu. The second, at No. 78, is dedicated to temporary exhibitions and also offers a documentation centre specialised in the cultures, ethnic groups, and traditional societies of the Guiana Shield.

Museum of French Guianese Culture
54-78 rue Madame Payé
97300 Cayenne

+594 (0)5 94 31 41 72

amazonian-museum-network.org/en

content.title: Saint-Joseph Church in Iracoubo: 19th-century Naive art

introduction.small: While thousands make a pilgrimage to this protected historical monument to see its stunning frescoes, very few learn the history of this unusual building from the late 19th century.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saint-Joseph Church in Iracoubo: 19th-century Naive art

paragraphs.text:
Prosper Raffray, a Catholic priest, began building this simple church soon after arriving in this remote village in 1886. The church funds set aside for the task soon ran out, and the villagers provided the necessary materials, labour, and money to complete the work. The building is now under the National Monuments supervision.

As the building was completed in 1893, Father Raffray, who personally donated five thousand francs to its construction, wanted to make this church a unique and personalised place with high-quality decoration, so he sought out the services of a convict named Huguet at the Iracoubo camp. For six years, Huguet dedicated himself to the task and covered the 600-sqm interior with frescoes each a masterpiece of Naive art, bringing out the best yet-popular themes.

Saint-Joseph church in Iracoubo
97350 Iracoubo

www.iracoubo.fr/patrimoine/eglise-saint-joseph/

content.title: Le Planeur Bleu: the fun and fascinating world of insects

introduction.small: This museum and association of the same name displays extraordinary collections of endemic butterflies and insects in French Guiana.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Planeur Bleu: the fun and fascinating world of insects

paragraphs.text:
Philippe Soler, a school teacher who has lived in the village of Cacao for 25 years, is the origin of this lively museum. After devoting a quarter of his life to the study of insects, their ecosystems, and their relationship with humans, he now puts on a show with his tenants-insects, both dead and alive and unveils some pretty amazing facts and figures about them. For, example, there are a staggering number of insects on the planet today, somewhere between three and eight million species, and they are particularly numerous in countries, like French Guiana, in the Intertropical Convergence Zone.

In a tank recreating their natural habitat, some are impressive; others, like the tarantula hawk, a spider wasp that hunts tarantulas, the black tunnel web spider, and the giant scorpion, are wrongly feared. The collection of butterflies is gorgeous and fascinating, as you can see in vivo their symbiotic relationships with flowers and ants, and their exceptional mimetic abilities.

There are also many artefacts, including Native American pottery and gold-panning equipment dating back to the 17th century.

 

Le Planeur Bleu Museum
Bourg de Cacao
97352 Roura

+594 (0)5 94 27 00 34

https://www.guyane-amazonie.fr/activites-de-loisirs/ASCCTG973V500095/detail/roura/musee-le-planeur-bleu

content.title: The Îles du Salut: from hell to paradise

introduction.small: Of these three volcanic rocks 14 km from Kourou, only Ile Royale and Ile Saint-Joseph can be visited. The most famous, Ile du Diable, aka Devil's Island, remains virtually inaccessible.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Îles du Salut: from hell to paradise

paragraphs.text:
From the Dreyfus Affair to Papillon, the stories of suffering connected to Devil's Island, the world's most notorious penal colony, are legion, reprised in many books and films. From 1854 to 1953 (when the last convicts where repatriated to mainland France), some 70,000 prisoners served their sentences at this former leper colony, in the most humiliating and inhumane conditions. It is finally in 1938 that the powers in place decided to shut the prison down, which actually took effect in 1947.

Totally run-down and located in the trajectory of the Ariane space rockets, the installations became the property of the CNES (National Centre for Space Studies), due to their strategic assets.

The tourist attraction and will to preserve this historical heritage have been reasons for major renovations of the Dreyfus house and various inmate celles on Devil's island. On Royal island, the warden's house has been converted into the Prison Museum.

Comité du Tourisme de la Guyane
(CTG - French Guiana Tourism Comittee)
12 rue Lallouette
97300 Cayenne

+594 (0)5 94 29 65 00

https://www.guyane-amazonie.fr/nature/PNACTG973V5001IQ/detail/kourou/iles-du-salut

content.title: Family excursion at the French Guiana zoo

introduction.small: This zoo for the 75 endangered species drawn from the more than 450 animals native to French Guiana offers them a peaceful shelter.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Family excursion at the French Guiana zoo

paragraphs.text:
With its zoological park, tropical greenhouses, botanical gardens, and great children's playground, there's so much to see and do here. Best to get up early to walk up those marked paths, not just to fit everything in but to beat the heat! The zoo houses 450 animals drawn from 75 different species, all in their natural habitats, sometimes in semi-freedom. The signage will bring you up to speed on all the essential elements of their ways of life, eating habits, and breeding rituals.

Among the many sights, discover some of the most emblematic Guianese species, including gigantic boas asleep in the treetops; squabbling families of howler monkeys, whose cry is the most powerful of all terrestrial mammals; and four species of caimans including the black caiman, endangered due to intensive poaching. A special space is reserved for these and other crocodiles, and the aviary rustles with multi-coloured beauties, like macaws, toucans, parakeets, and ibis. Children will have great fun testing their courage on the tree-canopy rope course.

French Guiana zoo
Cd 5, Pk 29
97355 Macouria

+594 (0)5 94 31 73 06

https://www.zoodeguyane.com

content.title: Mercure Cayenne Royal Amazonia Hotel, Guyanese luxury

introduction.small: In a fast-changing neighbourhood away from the noisy town centre, this is one of the best addresses in Cayenne.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mercure Cayenne Royal Amazonia Hotel, Guyanese luxury

paragraphs.text:
This hotel complex combines great design, natural beauty, and hotel expertise. On three floors, some with balcony and garden views, the 134 rooms (including 18 suites), provide a very quiet stay for business and holiday travellers looking to unwind and recharge. The Classic Rooms and Junior Suites immerse you in a harmonious cocoon, tastefully decorated and equipped with every modern comfort.

Among the strengths of the Mercure Cayenne Royal Amazonia, besides the pool, is the spa with hammam, Jacuzzi, and full roster of beauty, face, and body treatments.

The Brasserie Royale cosy restaurant serves fine French cuisine with creole influences. At the Royal Sushi Bar, a virtuoso Japanese chef makes specialities on demand, and his tempura, maki, and sashimi are executed with perfection.

Hôtel Mercure Cayenne Royal Amazonia
45 rue de l'Ara Bleu
97300 Cayenne

+594 (0)5 94 39 15 15

https://www.mercurecayenneroyalamazonia.fr/en/

Rooms: from 133 EUR

content.title: The Kaw-Roura National Nature Reserve: exceptional biodiversity

introduction.small: This nature reserve (aka the Kaw Swamp) occupies 94,700 hectares and straddles the municipalities of Roura, Regina and Kaw in a region that boasts the highest rainfall in French Guiana.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Kaw-Roura National Nature Reserve: exceptional biodiversity

paragraphs.text:
The Kaw marsh is one of six natural reserves in French Guiana, each created by the French state because of its exceptional and unique biodiversity. This wildlife sanctuary has been in existence since the Pleistocene era; until the colonial period, it was only peopled by Native American tribes. The remains of a village, along with vestiges of tools and engraved stones, were recently discovered on Mount Favard. Carbon-14 dating of charred wood and pottery shards shows that the village originated around 170 years AD.

The village of Kaw, a town completely surrounded by wetlands and a floating savannah, is a wild wonderland full of mysteries and surprises. Nicknamed the Everglades of French Guiana, this green kingdom is a bird-watching paradise, home to many species, including large wading birds and herons, as well as one of the biggest members of the order Crocodilia, the black caiman.

Marais de Kaw (Kaw-Roura National Nature Reserve)
97300 Cayenne

https://marais-kaw.com

content.title: Cacao: an authentic Hmong village

introduction.small: Starting in 1975, the Hmong ethnic group from Thailand, China, and Laos immigrated to the American continent to escape conflicts linked to the wars in Indochina.

paragraphs.text:
Welcomed by Catholics and supported by French officials, many Hmong from the Indochinese peninsula choose to settle in French Guiana, an under-populated department where the climate and flora are identical to the biotope in Laos. French Guiana greatly needed to develop its agriculture, as their fruits and vegetables up until then were purchased from the Surinamese and Brazilians.

The Hmong were given permission to create, in 1977, the village of Cacao, connected to the town of Roura, 70 km from Cayenne. After years of struggling to grow food on this harsh territory, these agrarian people have now successfully cultivated the land. They have also perpetuated their traditions and preserved their oral language, whilst integrating Romance writing skills.

At Sunday market, a colourful and lively affair, they proudly display their fruits and vegetables, as well as their beautifully embroidered fabrics and crafts.

Village of Cacao
97311 Roura

﻿www.roura.gf/tourisme-et-decouverte/escapades/bourg-de-cacao/

content.title: Guiana Space Centre: the European spaceport

introduction.small: Operational since 1968, the ‘Centre Spatial Guyanais' (CSG) in the coastal town of Kourou gives European states independent access to space. Satellite launches for all nationalities are done here.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Guiana Space Centre: the European spaceport

paragraphs.text:
December 1979 remains a historic date for the CNES (National Centre for Space Studies) with the saga of Ariane, the Véronique, Diamond, Soyuz and Vega launches, and now Ariane 5, which have taken place over a period of 48 years and represent an ongoing success. In the 1960s, when France was forced to abandon its Algerian military bases, it chose French Guiana as its new launching pad into space, and on Christmas Eve, 1979, the carrier rocket Ariane 1 was successfully launched from this site, which has since proven itself to be the most efficient space centre in the world, famous for its modernity and innovation. As a result, the backlog of orbital launch systems is consistently full.

The three-hour tour visits the launch pads, the bunker, and the Jupiter control centre, where the ground control team oversee launches. If you are lucky, you may even witness ongoing operations for the next space mission launch!

Centre Spatial Guyanais
(Guiana Space Centre)
97387 Kourou

+594 (0)5 94 33 71 92

cnes.fr/en

content.title: Le Paris Cayenne: a landmark brasserie

introduction.small: In an old colonial house, exotic woods and a beautiful light create the friendly atmosphere of the best restaurant in Cayenne.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Paris Cayenne: a landmark brasserie

paragraphs.text:
For more than 35 years, Paris Cayenne has topped the lists of food guides to the Guianese capital. Known for its Parisian bistro menu and cocktail bar-a cosy setting for festive gatherings-the kitchen attracts dynamic young talent, who learn to flourish here. You will love this simple yet inventive cuisine, which showcases the diversity and quality of local produce: spicy vegetable dishes, a good selection of wild fish, and absolutely exquisite rum-flambéed shrimp.
Classics French dishes - zebu hump in red fruit sauce, guinea fowl in cassava with jambu extracts and mashed sweet potatoes are served alongside more refreshing dishes: red tuna steak with sesame seeds, ginger soy sauce and aromatic white rice, or grilled salmon topped with a sour sauce and small crispy green cabbage... Vegetarians would not want to miss the famous cep mushrooms risotto or a fresh vegetables stew. The wine list is extensive, with a wide selection of great vintages from the world's finest wineries.

Le Paris Cayenne
59 rue Lallouette
97300 Cayenne

+594 (0)5 94 31 76 17

www.pariscayenne.fr

Menu: from 34 EUR

content.title: Le Bar des Palmistes: a legendary address

introduction.small: No trip to Cayenne can pass without a visit to this venerable institution, known for its festive atmosphere and the Cuban bands that brighten the weekends.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Bar des Palmistes: a legendary address

paragraphs.text:
With its gardens and palms, ancient colonial facades, and concentration of shops, the Place des Palmistes does not seem to have changed since the 1950s.
But do not be fooled by its laid-back atmosphere during the heat of the day. At night, this is the spot. This delightful period building, a historical monument built in 1890, is not just a chic hotel. It is also home to the best bar around, bar none.
Always packed and lively on the terrace or in the patio, for both lunch and dinner, the atmospheric spot serves delicious creole specialities, with a shrimp, tomato and basil tartare, smoked fish and shrimp accras, green pepper beef skewers and most especially its must-try homemade pizzas, served with spicy sauce which secret composition is preciously kept.

Le Bar des Palmistes
12 avenue du Général de Gaulle
97300 Cayenne

+594 (0)5 94 30 00 50

www.palmistes.com/restaurant/

Menu: from 24 EUR

content.title: Le Grillados: an address for insiders

introduction.small: Nicknamed 'Chicago', Cayenne's Chinatown district is constantly bustling with life. For lunch, make sure you venture to Le Grillados, one of the best addresses in town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Grillados: an address for insiders

paragraphs.text:
The address, kept fairly confidential, is frequented by local entrepreneurs, and city officials who like to have business lunches here because of the great food and very friendly atmosphere. Rustic and functional, a wooden terrace always crowded at lunchtime juts out over the canal.

The menu highlights family and generous recipes. Full of flavours, aromas and spices, they are based on seasonal products and the catch of the day. Regulars claim this is the spot for the best Creole cuisine. Among the most irresistible dishes are the pork Colombo, fish in chili peppers and the famous nassi, a sweet and savoury rice with cucumber and ginger served with chicken fricassee. Alternately, you may try some calalou, a very spicy dish cooked with vegetables, pork, shrimp, spinach and tomato, and served with fried bananas and rice. Finally, do not miss the essential coconut and peanut homemade ice creams for dessert.

Le Grillados
10 rue Henri Quintrie
97300 Cayenne

+594 (0)5 94 30 96 01

https://www.facebook.com/legrillados/

Menu: from 15 EUR

content.title: Hôtel des Roches: a heady mix of adventure and sun

introduction.small: On the coast, facing the famous Îles du Salut, the Hôtel des Roches is an ideal destination for relaxation and recreation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel des Roches: a heady mix of adventure and sun

paragraphs.text:
Close to L'Anse golf club, an 18-hole public course, the Aero Club of Kourou, maiden flight and pilot-training specialists, and the nautical centre for sailing enthusiasts, the rich bounty of sports activities makes this an attractive destination for couples and families with kids. The 99 comfortable rooms (including two suites) have balconies that take in the full length of a long beach equipped with lounge chairs, fringed with coconut palms.

The facilities are modern, with minibars in the rooms, Wi-Fi throughout, and some 30-satellite channels available. On the first floor is Le Paradisier, a panoramic restaurant serving gourmet French-Caribbean cuisine. The Sunday brunch is a highlight of the week.

For simpler fare, try the snack-bar hut on the beach. Now, the only thing left to do is relax!

Hôtel des Roches
Avenue des Roches
97310 Kourou

+594 (0)5 94 32 00 66

https://www.hoteldesroches.com/en

Rooms: from 90 EUR

content.title: Hôtel des Palmistes: the charm of a colonial house

introduction.small: A traditional creole building from the late 19th century, listed as a historical monument, is now a charming boutique hotel overlooking Cayenne's principal square, the Place des Palmistes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel des Palmistes: the charm of a colonial house

paragraphs.text:
An integral part of French Guiana's history, and witness to the passage of many of its greatest figures, the Hôtel des Palmistes combines traditional style, imposed by the building's fabulous architecture, with modern elegance. The result is a very relaxing and restful stay.

With some flair, the boutique hotel retains all its historical finery, including the original wooden floors, large living areas and delicate period ironwork weathered by time. The spacious nine rooms have colonial furniture and no shortage of character. Fully air-conditioned, they are equipped with satellite TV, a minibar, and a courtesy area with a coffee machine and tea kettle.

The excellent restaurant on the ground floor has been in operation since 1903, and the bar is probably the liveliest place in the city, keenly frequented by the local bourgeoisie and passing tourists alike.

Hôtel des Palmistes
12 avenue du Général de Gaulle
97300 Cayenne

+594 (0)5 94 30 00 50

www.palmistes.com/

Rooms: from 125 EUR

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Cayenne
content.introduction: Cayenne has an equatorial climate characterized by high humidity. Thanks to its ocean exposure and its nearness to the equator, the climate in Cayenne remains stable. Consequently, low temperatures vary little over the course of the year, between 22°C and 23°C on average (72°F–73°F). The same is true for the high temperatures which, from January to December, range from 29°C to 32°C on average (84°F–90°F). Rainfall is often quite heavy. The dry season runs from July to November.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in France is the Euro (EUR).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Cayenne Félix-Éboué International Airport
airports.description:
The Cayenne Félix-Éboué International Airport is located approximately 17 kilometres (11 miles) from Cayenne.
  • One terminal

Getting from the airport to Cayenne and back:
  • By car
    • Access to Cayenne's city centre via the N2 road and the N4 road.
    • Short- and long-term parking lots are located near the airport (free for 15 minutes, then EUR 3.50 for one hour and EUR 98.30 for 72 hours).
    • Several car rental companies have counters at the airport.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks just outside the airport. The fare to central Cayenne is about EUR 35.
  • Services: shops, newsstands.
  • Telephone: +594 (0)5 94 29 97 00 / +594 (0)5 94 29 97 52
  • Website: https://www.guyane.cci.fr/aeroport-felix-eboue/

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Cayenne
transportation.description: The recommended way to explore Cayenne and the coast of French Guiana is by rental car.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Cayenne, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organise your stay.

information.title: Cayenne Tourist Office
information.description:
Offers practical information and useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Address: 12 rue Louis Blanc, Cayenne
  • Opening hours: Monday to Friday 8:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and 2 p.m. to 5 p.m., Saturday 9:00 a.m. to 1 p.m.
  • Telephone: +594 (0)5 94 39 68 83
  • Website: www.ville-cayenne.fr/a-la-decouverte-de-cayenne/

information.title: French Guiana Tourism Committee (CTG)
information.description:
• Address: 12 rue Lalouette, 97300 Cayenne
  • Opening hours: Monday, Wednesday and Friday from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m., Tuesday and Thursday from 8 to 1 p.m. and 2 p.m. to 4:30 p.m.
  • Telephone: +594 (0)5 94 29 65 00
  • Website: https://www.guyane-amazonie.fr/

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description:
In order to travel in the best conditions and for your health and safety, we invite you to check all information regarding preventive measures and best practices to be respected, available on the official website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. Find out more about the measures taken to ensure safe travelling on our website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/page_flottante/information/coronavirus.htm#notre-engagement-sanitaire

See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Cayenne counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
A yellow fever vaccination certificate is required for travellers over one year of age.

For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38 quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr/
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Water
information.description: It is recommended to drink mineral water from sealed bottles in Cayenne.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic French phrases that will make your stay in Cayenne a little easier:
phrases: I don't understand: Je ne comprends pas
What time is it ?: Quelle heure est-il ?
How much is (…)?: Quel est le prix de (…) ?
Where can I find (…)?: Où puis-je trouver (…) ?
Where can I buy (…)?: Où puis-je acheter (…) ?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Cayenne
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Cayenne each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January–February : Cayenne Carnival (local event)
events.description: Carnival is the most important cultural event each year in Cayenne. From January to February, Cayenne's carnival draws thousands of visitors. Each weekend, the program of festivities includes music, processions, parades and masked balls, attended by the Touloulous, the queens of the carnival, dressed from head to toe!

events.title: March or April: Easter Monday (national holiday)
May 1 : Labour Day (national holiday)
events.description: On the first of May, it is customary to offer a sprig of lily-of-the-valley to close ones. Many vendors occupy the pavement on that occasion!

events.title: May 8: Victory Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the Allied victory in Europe that ended World War II on this day in 1945. Various ceremonies are held around town.

events.title: June 10 : Abolition of Slavery Day (local holiday)
events.description: On this day in 1848, slavery was abolished in French Guiana. Many events are scheduled to commemorate this anniversary across the country: theatre, music and dance performances as well as conferences.

events.title: June 21: Fête de la Musique (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Major popular celebration in Metropolitan France, overseas territories and abroad. Various free concerts take place all over French Guiana.

events.title: July 14 : Bastille Day (national holiday)
events.description: This holiday celebrates the storming of the Bastille prison in 1789, the key event marking the beginning of the French Revolution. It plays as a symbol of the end of the privileges enjoyed by the clergy and the aristocracy. In Cayenne, a military parade is staged each year on July 14<sup>th</sup>.

events.title: August 15 : Assumption Day (national holiday)
events.description: Still very popular in French Guiana, it is celebrated with numerous processions and religious ceremonies.

events.title: Third weekend in September: European Heritage Days (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: The aim of the European Heritage Days is to open up numerous sites and monuments, many of which are normally closed to the public, such as castles and private collections. A great opportunity to visit the Guiana Space Center in Kourou, open to the public for the occasion.

events.title: October: Cayenne Festival (local holiday)
events.description: Many events are organised as part of the Cayenne Festival throughout the month of October: a pageant to elect Miss French Guiana, a jazz festival, concerts, a flea market, dance parties celebrating Guianese Creole folklore, etc.

events.title: November 11: Remembrance Day (national holiday)
events.description: On this day, French citizens gather at war memorials to commemorate the signing of the 1918 Armistice officially bringing an end to the First World War.

events.title: December 31: New Year's Eve (national event)
events.description: On the night of December 31<sup>st</sup>, the atmosphere is particularly festive on the streets of Cayenne, with families and friends celebrating the new year.

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: GOVERNMENT OFFICES
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 7:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 5:30 p.m.

banks.title: BANKS
banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 7:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 5:30 p.m. (closed Wednesday afternoons)

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime: No daylight savings in French Guiana
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Cayenne like elsewhere in France, a service charge is always included in the bill. If you are particularly pleased with the service, you may certainly leave a few extra euros on the table. But this additional tip is neither expected nor necessary.
